Perspectives on Perception
2. Perspectives on Perception

Most classical Indian philosophical schools accept perception as the
primary means of knowledge, but differ on the nature, kinds and
objects of perceptual knowledge. Here we first survey Buddhist and
orthodox Hindu schools’ definitions of perception (excluding
Vaiśeṣika and Yoga schools since they simply take on board
Nyāya and Sāṃkhya ideas, respectively) and note the
issues raised by these definitions. As mentioned above, the orthodox
schools generally accept both non-conceptualized (indeterminate) and
conceptualized (determinate) perceptual states in sharp contrast to
the Buddhist view that perception is always non-conceptualized or
indeterminate awareness.
